SOURCE.description: In GPAC, a source is an input element that provides media data to be processed. It is typically the starting point of a media processing pipeline.

SINK.description: A sink in GPAC is an output element that receives processed media data. It is usually the endpoint of a media processing pipeline.

INPUT.description: An input refers to any data fed into the GPAC processing system, including video, audio, and other multimedia streams.

OUTPUT.description: Output in GPAC refers to the processed data that is generated after media processing, ready for storage or display.

PID.description: PID stands for Packet Identifier. It is used in GPAC to uniquely identify different streams within a media file, such as audio, video, and subtitles.

PACKET.description: Packets is unit of data transmitted over a network or stored in a media file. In GPAC, packets are processed to extract media streams.

DATA.description: Data in GPAC refers to the raw media content, including video frames, audio samples, and subtitles, that is processed and manipulated.

STREAM.description: A stream is a sequence of media data (audio, video, etc.) that is processed by GPAC. Streams are identified by PIDs and can be multiplexed or demultiplexed.

MEDIA.description: Media refers to various types of content such as video, audio, and images. GPAC processes different media types to enable playback, editing, and streaming.

FRAME.description: A frame is a single image in a sequence of images that make up a video. GPAC processes frames during video encoding and decoding.

PROPERTY.description: Properties in GPAC refer to attributes of media streams or filters, such as resolution, bitrate, and codec type, that affect processing.

CODEC.description: A codec is a software or hardware tool that encodes or decodes media data. GPAC supports various codecs for compressing and decompressing media streams.

SESSION.description: A session in GPAC is a context for managing the lifecycle of media processing tasks, including loading, configuring, and executing filters.

LINK.description: Links in GPAC connect different filters and processing elements, forming a processing chain or graph. They facilitate the flow of media data.

REMUX.description: Remuxing is the process of taking encoded media streams from one container format and repackaging them into another container format without altering the actual media data.

CHAIN.description: A chain in GPAC is a sequence of connected filters that process media data in a specific order. Chains define the processing pipeline.

GRAPH.description: A graph in GPAC represents the entire media processing workflow, consisting of nodes (filters) and edges (connections) that define data flow.

DECODING.description: Decoding is the process of converting compressed media data back into its original format. GPAC uses various codecs to decode audio and video streams.

REFRAMER.description: A reframer in GPAC adjusts the timing and structure of media frames to meet specific requirements, such as alignment for streaming.

ENCRYPT.description: Encryption in GPAC refers to the process of securing media content by converting it into a code to prevent unauthorized access. GPAC supports various encryption standards like CENC and ISMA.

ENCODE.description: Encoding in GPAC is the process of converting raw media data into a compressed format using codecs. This is essential for reducing file sizes and preparing media for streaming or storage.

MP4.description: MP4 is a standardized multimedia file format for storing video, audio, subtitles and still images. It is widely used for streaming and media storage.

FILTER.description: In GPAC, a filter is a processing unit that consumes and produces data packets. Filters can be chained together to form a media processing pipeline.

TRACK.description: A track is a single stream of media data, such as audio or video, within a multimedia file.

CHUNK.description: A chunk is a portion of media data used for storage and transmission. Chunks are relatively small blocks of data that can be used to divide larger multimedia files into more manageable parts.

SEGMENT.description: A segment is a timed portion of a media file used primarily in adaptive streaming protocols like DASH and HLS. Each segment represents a specific time interval of the media content, allowing for dynamic adaptation to network conditions.

SAMPLE.description: A sample is an individual unit of audio or video data used in encoding and decoding processes.

MPEG.description: MPEG (Moving Picture Experts Group) is a working group that sets standards for audio and video compression and transmission.

TILE.description: A tile is a portion of a video frame, often used in advanced video coding techniques like HEVC.

HEVC.description: HEVC (High Efficiency Video Coding) is a video compression standard designed as a successor to the widely used AVC (H.264).

PIPE.description: A pipe is a method of inter-process communication that allows data to flow from one process to another.

DUMP.description: A dump in GPAC refers to the process of outputting raw media data to a file or stream.

ISOBMFF.description: ISOBMF (ISO Base Media File Format) is a file format that forms the basis for many other file formats, such as MP4 and MOV.

RTCP.description: RTCP (Real-Time Control Protocol) is a companion protocol to RTP (Real-Time Protocol) that provides out-of-band control information for an RTP flow. It is primarily used for quality of service (QoS) monitoring and to convey information about participants in ongoing RTP sessions.

TIMESHIFT.description: Timeshift refers to the capability of a media player or streaming service to pause, rewind, or fast-forward live broadcast content. This feature allows users to view content on their own schedule without missing any part of the broadcast.

BITSTREAM.description: A bitstream is a sequence of bits that represent encoded media data.

SEQUENCE.description: A sequence in GPAC refers to a series of frames or samples that are processed together.

COMPOSITOR.description: The compositor in GPAC is a filter used for rendering video and graphics, managing the display of visual elements.

FFMPEG.description: FFmpeg is a free and open-source project consisting of a vast software suite for handling video, audio, and other multimedia files and streams.

BIFS.description: BIFS (Binary Format for Scenes) is a binary format used to represent and encode multimedia scenes, part of the MPEG-4 standard.

H264.description: H.264 is a widely used video compression standard that allows for high-quality video at lower bitrates.

BLOCK.description: A block is a chunk of media data processed as a unit in encoding and decoding.

MULTICAST.description: Multicast is a method of data transmission where data is sent to multiple destinations simultaneously.

LATENCY.description: Latency is the delay between the input and output of a data processing system, important in streaming and real-time applications.

SIGNAL.description: A signal in GPAC refers to a type of data that triggers events or actions in media processing.

OFFSCREEN.description: Offscreen processing in GPAC involves rendering or processing media data outside the visible display area.

RFRAWID.description: RFRAWID is a unique identifier used in GPAC to reference raw data streams.

TTML.description: TTML (Timed Text Markup Language) is a standard for representing timed text media, such as subtitles and captions.

BINARY.description: Binary data in GPAC refers to data represented in binary format, essential for encoding and processing media files.

BITRATE.description: Bitrate is the number of bits processed per unit of time, important for defining the quality and bandwidth usage of multimedia streams.

LIBGPAC.description: LibGPAC is the core library of GPAC, providing essential functionalities for multimedia processing.

HEIF.description: HEIF (High Efficiency Image File Format) is a file format for individual images and image sequences, based on the HEVC standard.

WEBVTT.description: WebVTT (Web Video Text Tracks) is a format used for displaying timed text tracks, such as subtitles or captions, with HTML5 video.

NHNT.description: NHNT (Non-Hierarchical Naming Tables) is a format used in GPAC for structuring media data.

ISMA.description: ISMA (Internet Streaming Media Alliance) is a standard for streaming multimedia content over the internet.

CAROUSEL.description: A carousel in GPAC refers to a method of cyclically transmitting media data, often used in broadcast and streaming applications.

SUBSAMPLE.description: Subsampling in GPAC involves reducing the resolution or frequency of media data for efficient processing and transmission.

AVMIX.description: AVMix is a process in GPAC for mixing audio and video streams into a single synchronized output.

CUE.description: A cue in GPAC is a marker used to indicate specific points in a media stream for navigation or synchronization.

FLUSH.description: Flushing in GPAC involves clearing buffers and ensuring all processed data is output, important for maintaining data integrity.

DASH.description: DASH (Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP) is an adaptive bitrate streaming technique that enables high-quality streaming of media content over the internet delivered from conventional HTTP web servers.

DECODER.description: A decoder is a device or software that converts compressed media data back into its original format. GPAC uses various codecs to decode audio and video streams.

MANIFEST.description: A manifest is a file that provides information about the structure and components of a multimedia presentation, often used in streaming protocols like DASH and HLS.

BUFFER.description: Rebuffering in GPAC refers to the process of refilling the buffer when data is being streamed, helping to prevent playback interruptions due to insufficient data.

ENCODER.description: An encoder is a device or software that converts raw media data into a compressed format using codecs. This is essential for reducing file sizes and preparing media for streaming or storage.

MULTIPLEXER.description: A multiplexer is a device or software that combines multiple signals into one signal over a shared medium. In GPAC, multiplexing is used to combine audio, video, and other data streams into a single container file like MP4.

CONNECTION.description: A connection in GPAC refers to the relationship between filters in a processing graph. They define how data flows from one filter to another.

LAYER.description: A layer in GPAC refers to the hierarchical levels of data processing or display, such as video layers in a compositing process.

PIPELINE.description: A pipeline in GPAC is a sequence of connected filters that process media data in a specific order, defining the media processing workflow.

TRANSCODE.description: Transcoding is the process of converting a media file from one format to another. GPAC supports transcoding for various media formats to ensure compatibility and optimize playback.

TEMI.description: TEMI (Timed External Media Information) is a standard used to synchronize external media with broadcast content, allowing for accurate timing and synchronization of additional media streams.

OVERLAY.description: An overlay in GPAC is a graphical element that is superimposed on a video stream, such as subtitles, watermarks, or interactive graphics.

ISOMEDIA.description: ISO Media refers to the family of media file formats based on the ISO Base Media File Format (ISOBMFF), including MP4 and MOV.

COMPRESSION.description: Compression is the process of reducing the size of a media file by encoding data using fewer bits. GPAC supports various compression algorithms to optimize storage and transmission.

BROADCAST.description: Broadcast in GPAC refers to the transmission of multimedia content to multiple receivers simultaneously, often used in live streaming and TV broadcasting.

REPAIR.description: Repair in GPAC refers to the process of fixing errors or corruption in media files to ensure proper playback and processing.

INTERLEAVE.description: Interleaving in GPAC refers to the process of mixing different types of media data for synchronous playback, ensuring that audio and video streams remain in sync.

MACRO.description: A macro in GPAC is a predefined sequence of instructions or commands that can be used to automate repetitive tasks in media processing.

REBUFFER.description: Rebuffering in GPAC refers to the process of refilling the buffer when data is being streamed, helping to prevent playback interruptions due to insufficient data.

OPENGL.description: OpenGL (Open Graphics Library) is a cross-language, cross-platform API for rendering 2D and 3D vector graphics.

WEBGL.description: WebGL (Web Graphics Library) is a JavaScript API for rendering high-performance interactive 3D and 2D graphics within any compatible web browser without the use of plug-ins.
